text: - (narrator) The end is near.

- Now, we know that Thor's
hammer has gone away

and it is replaced in Infinity
War with a new weapon.

And so what you get is
a little bit of a taste,

a closer look, at how such
weapons are manufactured.

One of the really fun
things that's going on

in contemporary, real
physics research is that
there's very exotic phases of matter

that can occur in the universe
in extreme situations.

One of the extreme
situations is when you have

a lot of gravity that allows
you to compress that matter
into a very, very compact, dense form.

And a lot of gravity's
available when you have,
for example, the interior of a star.
So a well-known exotic place is the core
of what's called a neutron star.

So much of the matter,
imagine having as much matter

as our sun, which is a
huge object, or even more,

but compress that down to the
size of, let's say, Manhattan.
New York City.
That is incredibly dense.

The matter inside takes on
a very, very different form.

It takes on very, very
different properties.

One of the early conjectures
from the Marvel Universe,
and you see a little bit of it
in the Marvel Cinematic Universe as well,

is the idea that maybe
material like that is where

Thor's hammer gets some
of its incredible density.

- So long entrusted with
the mighty hammer, Mjolnir,
forged in the heart of a dying star.
Its power has no equal,
as a weapon to destroy
or as a tool to build.

- Now, we know that Thor's
hammer has gone away,

and it is replaced in Infinity
War with a new weapon.

And, so what you get is
a little bit of a taste,

a closer look at how such
weapons are manufactured.
And that's sort of a fun thing,
because you can then speculate about

whether the properties
of those instruments

are just from the physics
of those exotic materials
that you'd find in the cores of stars,
or whether they're just holders,

channelers, if you like,
of Thor's inherent ability.

And I think we learn a little
bit from Thor: Ragnarok
that the power's really in him,
and the hammer's really more of a channel.

And I think the skill, then,
that these dwarves have,
is how to build the weapons that are
the best possible channels
for the inherent power that our hero has.
And so the new device, the new hammer,

Stormbreaker, is presumably
an even better design

than Mjolnir had for
channeling Thor's abilities.
(soft, upbeat music)
